summary: Flutter web app for a first-person RV driver-view journey: user clicks “Start Journey” to begin travel, reaches 3 break stops/checkpoints in order triggered by user clicks on the journey screen (not timed), must select at least 1 water-related activity at each stop (additional selections allowed) to continue, sees an interactive view of the selected action(s), then continues traveling; after the post-break-stop-3 interruption is resolved, show the final combined campfire + congratulation/badge screen after ~2 seconds (not after a long travel timer); rest of the flow remains unchanged.
architectural_notes: Travel segments should support video playback with timed checkpoint triggers (elapsed time based).
Add an internal (not overtly exposed) resource system for water consumption tied to activities.
Add a post-checkpoint-3 interruption state that pauses travel playback until the user acknowledges “Issue resolved,” then resumes toward a final destination scene (campfire).
Post-checkpoint-3 interruption should trigger after a short delay (~2–3s) following completion of checkpoint 3 action playback, not immediately.
Checkpoint progression should be triggered by user click interaction on the journey/travel screen (not by elapsed-time video timers).
Checkpoint UI terminology should be “Break Stop” (not “Checkpoint”) throughout the app.
Activity selection validation: require at least 1 activity selected to continue; allow selecting more than 1 (no longer 'exactly 1').
End-state UI: campfire + congratulatory checkpoint-1 message + RV badge + snap/selfie invite should be presented together on a single screen with attractive styling.
Final destination/campfire arrival must not depend on a long (e.g., 60s) final travel timer; after “Issue resolved”, transition to the campfire end screen after ~2 seconds.
known_issues: Traveling video/scenery is missing during travel segments.
During road/travel segments, the background is still missing; travel should show animations/video or at least changing images.
Campfire end screen does not appear shortly after “Issue resolved” (currently blocked by final travel segment/timer).

existing_features.title: Create a single-page interactive experience that starts in a first-person RV driver-view “traveling” scene, showing a seated-driver perspective view on screen.
Implement a 3-checkpoint flow where the user reaches exactly three checkpoints in order; at each checkpoint, present 3–4 actions to choose from before allowing the user to continue traveling.
After the user completes the actions at each checkpoint, transition back to a traveling state and then display the next driver-view scene for the next segment of travel.
Add a simple progress indicator showing the current segment/checkpoint (e.g., ‘Traveling to Checkpoint 2’, ‘Checkpoint 2 of 3’) and reflect state changes as the user advances.
Apply a coherent visual theme across the app (colors, typography, spacing, and component styling) suitable for an RV road-trip interface, and keep it consistent on all screens.
Add the required generated images as static assets under frontend/public/assets/generated and use them as the backgrounds for the travel segments/checkpoints (no backend image serving).

Add an initial start screen state that shows a primary button labeled "Start Journey"; the RV experience (traveling video/timed checkpoints/progress) must not begin until the user clicks "Start Journey".

Replace the static traveling background experience with a traveling RV front-view video during traveling segments (driver seat / through-windshield perspective). The first checkpoint must appear after ~60 seconds of continuous traveling playback; checkpoints 2 and 3 must also be triggered by elapsed traveling time (same duration unless configured otherwise in code).
Update checkpoint action selection rules so the user must choose either 1 or 2 activities (no more than 2) from the activities shown at that checkpoint before continuing.

After the user confirms their 1–2 selected activities at a checkpoint, show an interactive "action playback" view that represents the selected actions (e.g., a short sequence/cards/steps for each selected activity) before transitioning back to traveling.

Implement a hidden water-consumption mechanic: every activity selection must consume some amount of water internally, but the UI must not explicitly mention water, hydration, or water consumption as the reason for any effects. Any user-facing feedback must be indirect/neutral (e.g., general "supplies" or "resources" wording) and must remain subtle.

Fix the missing traveling video/scenery during travel segments so that users always see either (a) the RV front-view traveling video or (b) a reliable visual fallback if the video cannot be loaded/played.

Update the checkpoint activity options so the actions are mostly water-related tasks (e.g., cooking, cleaning, freshen up, grab coffee/tea, refreshments), while keeping the existing 1–2 selection rule and the hidden internal consumption mechanic.

After the user completes the 3rd checkpoint’s action playback, force the journey to come to a halt due to an unidentified issue; present a user action labeled "Issue resolved" and only resume the journey after the user clicks it.
After the user clicks "Issue resolved", continue the journey to a final destination scene where there is a campfire, and then show the end-of-journey completion UI.
Ensure the on-road traveling view always shows visible scenery (either the RV travel video or an animated fallback) and never renders as a blank/black background during travel segments.

Improve TravelVideoScene so it robustly detects non-playing video states (e.g., no 'playing' event, stalled, waiting, or prolonged loading) and switches to a fallback mode that includes subtle motion (animation) rather than a purely static image.

Ensure TravelVideoScene correctly resets its internal timers and playback/fallback detection each time a new travel segment starts, so that subsequent travel segments (after checkpoints/transitions) also reliably show scenery and trigger timed checkpoint/destination progression.

Delay the transition into the post-checkpoint-3 journey halt issue by ~2–3 seconds after the user completes the 3rd checkpoint’s Action Playback (do not show the halt issue overlay immediately on the last Action Playback completion).

Update checkpoint activity selection validation so the user must select at least 2 activities before continuing (while still enforcing a maximum of 2 selections). Update the checkpoint overlay guidance text and disabled-button messaging accordingly in English.
Remove or replace any checkpoint activity option that is not related to water-involved tasks so that all remaining activity options are water-related across all checkpoints.

Change the traveling segments so that reaching a checkpoint (and showing the checkpoint activity overlay) is triggered by a user click/tap anywhere on the journey/traveling screen, rather than by an elapsed-time/timer-based trigger.

Update TravelVideoScene to support click-to-advance behavior by removing/neutralizing its travel-duration timer logic for checkpoint arrival (while keeping video playback health monitoring and animated fallback scenery intact).

Update RVExperience to wire the new click-to-advance trigger from the traveling view to the existing startCheckpoint(segment) logic (and ensure the timed travelDuration/onTravelTimeReached path is no longer used for checkpoints).
Adjust user-facing on-screen guidance text during traveling to reflect click-to-advance (English only).

Rename all user-facing references of “Checkpoint 1/2/3” to “Break Stop 1/2/3” and any “Checkpoint X of 3” phrasing to “Break Stop X of 3” across the UI (including overlay headers, progress indicator status text, and transition messaging).

Change break-stop activity selection validation to require exactly 1 activity (maximum 1) before the user can continue, updating selection toggling rules, disabled-state behavior, and all related English guidance/CTA text accordingly.

Add a new celebration/badge screen that is shown after the user has completed all three break-stop activities and then resolves the post-break-stop-3 issue; the celebration screen must display the exact text: “You have got an RV badge. Take a snap with our team.”

Update the Break Stop activity selection rules so that selecting at least 1 activity is mandatory to continue, but the user may optionally select more than 1 activity (no maximum). This must include updating the selection toggling behavior and validation so the user is never blocked for selecting multiple activities.

Update the Break Stop overlay UI copy and states to reflect the new selection rule (minimum 1, no maximum), including removing any “Maximum 1 activity” messaging and any UI behavior that visually implies a maximum selection cap. All user-facing text must be in English.

Update the RV flow state logic to support carrying 1+ selected activities from the Break Stop overlay into Action Playback (instead of enforcing exactly one). Internal resource consumption must still be applied for every selected activity, and the UI must remain indirect/subtle (no explicit mention of water/hydration).

Change the end-of-journey UX so that the campfire arrival and the congratulation/badge/selfie invitation are presented together in a single, attractive end screen. The screen must: (1) show a campfire setup, (2) congratulate the user on reaching “Checkpoint 1”, (3) state they earned an RV badge, and (4) invite them to take a snap/selfie with the team. The rest of the journey flow must remain unchanged.

Ensure the badge/selfie invitation text is preserved exactly as: “You have got an RV badge. Take a snap with our team.” when shown on the final combined campfire end screen (even if the surrounding UI text changes).

Update the post–Break Stop 3 flow so that after the user clicks the "Issue resolved" button, the app shows the final campfire end screen after ~2 seconds (instead of waiting for a ~60s traveling-to-destination timer). This campfire appearance must not be gated on travel video playback starting successfully.

If the app still uses an intermediate "traveling-to-destination" state/screen between "Issue resolved" and the campfire end screen, shorten its duration to ~2 seconds and ensure it always transitions to the destination state automatically; update any related progress/status text to remain accurate and in English.

Add the following exact introductory/reminder copy to the experience UI so users see it before or at the start of the journey: "You are going on trip in RV. You dont see everything that's happening. Remember your choices!". Implement this in the Start Journey screen (frontend/src/components/rv/StartJourneyScreen.tsx) as additional visible text near the existing introduction content, without changing the sentence text, punctuation, or spelling.

new_feature_requests.summary: Build a simple website UI showing an RV driver-view scene (first-person seated driver perspective).
Add 3 checkpoints where the user can choose 3–4 actions at each checkpoint.
After completing checkpoint actions, transition back to traveling and then display the next driver-view scene.
Add a “Start Journey” button that begins the experience.
Use a traveling RV front-view video for the travel segments and trigger checkpoints based on elapsed time (e.g., first checkpoint after ~1 minute).
After selecting activities, show an interactive view representing the selected actions before continuing the journey.
Implement a hidden water-consumption mechanic where all activities consume water but the UI should not make the water linkage obvious.
Target implementation as Flutter Web (instead of a generic web stack).
Update checkpoint activity options to be mostly water-related (e.g., cooking, cleaning, freshen up, coffee/tea, refreshments).
After the 3rd checkpoint, force the journey to halt due to an unidentified issue and require an “Issue resolved” user action to resume travel.
After the 3rd checkpoint action playback completes, delay the post-checkpoint-3 “Issue” interruption by ~2–3 seconds (do not show it immediately).

Add a repository documentation file that (1) clearly states the app cannot be reimplemented in Flutter within this build system and will remain implemented as a React + TypeScript frontend with a Motoko backend, and (2) provides step-by-step instructions for downloading/exporting the full source code and running it locally (including required tooling and the exact commands to install dependencies, start the frontend, and run/build/deploy with dfx).
Trigger checkpoint activity/overlay when the user clicks somewhere on the journey screen (click-to-advance), instead of using timed/elapsed travel playback to show checkpoints.
Rename “Checkpoint 1/2/3” to “Break Stop 1/2/3” across the UI (including progress/guidance text).
Update activity selection rules so only 1 activity is mandatory (user must pick at least 1), but users may choose one or more activities if they wish.
Change end-of-journey completion UI to congratulate on reaching Checkpoint 1 and show a campfire setup, indicate the user earned an RV badge, and invite them to take a snap/selfie with the team.
Combine the campfire portion and the congratulation/badge/invite messaging into a single attractive end screen.
After the last Break Stop, once the user clicks “Issue resolved”, show the final combined campfire end screen after ~2 seconds (remove/avoid any ~60s final travel timer gating campfire).

Add introductory/on-screen copy: "You are going on trip in RV. You dont see everything that's happening. Remember your choices!" (exact text) in the experience UI (e.g., start screen or early journey guidance).

projectName: Interactive RV Driver-View Website with 3 Checkpoints and Action Choices
